metadata.production_notes: Oscar Wilde meets Mark Twain - sharp social commentary wrapped in humor and heart. Think 'The Grand Budapest Hotel' meets 'The Social Network' in an oppressive regime
metadata.visual_style: Contrasts - gray oppressive exteriors vs. vibrant digital world in her screens

logline.protagonist_description: a wickedly clever 18-year-old coder in a collapsing economy
logline.inciting_conflict: creates AI-powered money-making systems to save her family
logline.antagonistic_force: but her success attracts the attention of a regime official who wants to exploit her talents
logline.stakes: her freedom, her family's safety, and the underground network of people she's helping
logline.unique_hook: and must choose between staying invisible or using her platform to spark change
logline.complete_logline: A wickedly clever 18-year-old coder in a collapsing economy creates AI-powered money-making systems to save her family, but her success attracts the attention of a regime official who wants to exploit her talents, forcing her to choose between staying invisible or using her platform to spark change.

theme.primary_theme: True wealth is measured in human connection, not currency
theme.thematic_question: In a world where survival requires cleverness, when does self-preservation become self-imprisonment?
thematic_statements: Technology can liberate or isolate depending on intent
Individual genius means nothing without community
The most revolutionary act is choosing to stay and fight rather than escape
Real currency is trust, not cryptocurrency
symbol_motifs: Broken/glitching screens - system failures both digital and governmental
Empty storefronts transformed by projection art - beauty despite scarcity
Her grandmother's recipe book - analog wisdom vs. digital knowledge
Pigeons carrying messages - old-world connection in surveillance state
theme.thematic_resolution: She realizes that her algorithms' true value wasn't making money—it was creating a network of mutual aid that government couldn't control. The message matters more than the medium.

protagonist.name: LUNA REYES
protagonist.occupation: Computer science university dropout / freelance coder / digital entrepreneur
protagonist.external_goal: Generate enough money through her automated systems to get her family out of the country
protagonist.internal_need: Learn that running away (digitally or physically) isn't the answer; building community is
protagonist.fatal_flaw: Uses intelligence as a shield; believes she's smarter than everyone and can solve everything alone; dismissive of 'analog' solutions and human messiness
protagonist.unique_skill: Prodigious coder who can build sophisticated AI systems; sees patterns in chaos; can gamify anything; sharp wit that disarms people
protagonist.backstory_hook: Child prodigy who won international coding competitions; dropped out of university when her father lost his professorship to brain drain; watched her family's savings evaporate overnight due to hyperinflation; taught herself crypto and AI to survive

character_arc.act_1_state: Cynical, isolated, works alone, trusts only code, preparing to escape, mocks 'analog' solutions, keeps emotional distance even from family
character_arc.midpoint_transformation: Realizes her network is accidentally creating real community; people aren't just using her tools—they're organizing, meeting, helping each other
character_arc.act_3_state: Embraces community leadership, combines digital and human solutions, chooses to stay and build rather than escape, opens her heart
character_arc.arc_type: positive change arc - from isolated genius to community leader; from digital escapist to present revolutionary

relationships.ally_mentor: ABUELA CARMEN - her grandmother, former philosophy professor, provides analog wisdom
relationships.love_interest: MATEO - street artist and 'analog activist' who initially clashes with her digital-only approach
relationships.family: Mother (ISABEL) - nurse working double shifts; Father (RICARDO) - former economics professor, now taxi driver, defeated by system
relationships.rival: VALERIA - former friend from coding competitions, now working for the regime, represents the 'sell-out' path
relationships.comic_relief: TÍO FELIX - uncle who runs bodega, provides physical safe space, terrible with technology but great with people

protagonist.voice_characteristics: Quick wit, dry sarcasm, references pop culture and philosophy interchangeably, code-switches between technical jargon and street slang, uses humor as armor, increasingly vulnerable as story progresses
signature_phrases: It's never just ones and zeros
I don't do feelings, I do functions

antagonist.name: COMANDANTE TERESA VEGA
antagonist.occupation: Director of Digital Security for the Ministry of Technology and Progress
antagonist.external_goal: Recruit or neutralize Luna; harness her technology for regime control and personal enrichment
antagonist.internal_motivation: Believes order and control are the only answers to chaos; genuine conviction that she's saving the country from itself; sees Luna as both threat and opportunity
antagonist.philosophy: Chaos requires control. Individual freedom is a luxury collapsing societies can't afford. Someone must make the hard choices.
antagonist.backstory_hook: Was once an idealistic engineer who believed technology could save the country; watched reformers fail; made pragmatic choice to work within system; now trapped by choices she's made; sees younger self in Luna
antagonist.unique_strength: Sophisticated understanding of technology; vast surveillance network; can be charming and persuasive; genuinely believes she's the hero of her story
antagonist.connection_to_protagonist: Offered Luna's father his professorship back—if he convinces Luna to join the regime. Knows Luna's systems intimately because she's been monitoring them. Represents the 'pragmatic sellout' path Luna could take.

antagonistic_arc.introduction: Appears reasonable, even sympathetic—offers Luna legitimate job with good pay
antagonistic_arc.revelation: Her 'reasonable' offer comes with strings—surveillance on citizens, control systems
antagonistic_arc.escalation: When Luna refuses, threatens family, friends, network
antagonistic_arc.final_state: Desperate to control Luna's growing influence, willing to destroy what she can't control

henchmen_structure.lieutenant: CAPTAIN RAMOS - tech specialist, true believer in digital authoritarianism, no nuance
henchmen_structure.specialists: Cyber surveillance team, social media manipulation unit
henchmen_structure.wildcards: VALERIA - Luna's former friend, now regime insider, conflicted

antagonist.complexity_notes: NOT a cartoon villain. She makes good points about chaos and security. Luna must counter her philosophy with something better than naive idealism. Final confrontation is ideological as much as physical.

mentor_figure.name: ABUELA CARMEN (Grandmother)
mentor_figure.function: Provides analog wisdom, historical context, emotional grounding; represents pre-digital values
mentor_figure.arc: Initially dismissive of Luna's 'computer games'; comes to understand technology's revolutionary potential; teaches Luna that algorithms need philosophy
mentor_figure.signature_trait: Quotes philosophers while cooking; still writes in journals; maintains illegal library
mentor_figure.fate: Briefly detained in Act 2B to pressure Luna; emerges unbowed, having organized fellow detainees
mentor_figure.key_dialogue: 'Mija, you can't algorithm your way out of being human. Trust me, philosophers tried for millennia.'

comic_relief.name: TÍO FELIX (Uncle)
comic_relief.role: Bodega owner, family clown, surprisingly shrewd
comic_relief.function: Safe house for meetings, lightens tension, provides street-level intel, represents everyday resilience
comic_relief.arc: Seems technologically hopeless; reveals he's been using Luna's systems brilliantly in analog ways
comic_relief.signature_trait: Constant tech mishaps played for comedy; runs elaborate analog black market network; 'accidentally' always where he needs to be
comic_relief.running_gag: Can't unlock his own phone but somehow coordinates entire neighborhood supply chain

love_interest.name: MATEO SILVA
love_interest.function: Romantic interest, ideological counterpoint, bridge to physical community
love_interest.arc: From digital skeptic to understanding tech's revolutionary potential; teaches Luna that movements need faces, not just code
love_interest.signature_trait: Creates projection art on buildings; quotes Oscar Wilde and Marx in street slang; passionate but thoughtful
love_interest.chemistry_factor: Opposites attract - she's all head, he's all heart; she codes alone, he organizes crowds; witty verbal sparring that evolves into genuine partnership
love_interest.key_scene: Teaches Luna spray painting while she teaches him coding—visual metaphor for synthesis
love_interest.in_danger_when: Arrested during peaceful protest Act 2B; Luna must risk exposure to get him out

emotional_anchor.name: ISABEL REYES (Mother)
emotional_anchor.function: Represents sacrifice, why Luna fights, moral compass
emotional_anchor.arc: Initially wants Luna to 'keep her head down'; comes to support her daughter's choices; revealed to be helping Luna's network access medicine
emotional_anchor.in_danger_when: Threatened with job loss and arrest in Act 3 if Luna doesn't comply
emotional_anchor.key_relationship: Most important bond; Luna's need to protect her drives early choices; mother's belief in her enables final choice

fallen_friend.name: VALERIA CONTRERAS
fallen_friend.role: Luna's former coding competition partner, now regime tech specialist
fallen_friend.function: Represents path not taken; provides intel (conflicted); moral complexity
fallen_friend.arc: Starts as apparent betrayer; revealed to be feeding Luna information while appearing loyal to regime; must choose side in climax
fallen_friend.signature_trait: Speaks in corporate buzzwords; drinks expensive coffee in poverty; clearly miserable despite 'success'
fallen_friend.key_moment: Act 3 - chooses Luna over regime at personal cost, helps take down surveillance system

father_figure.name: RICARDO REYES (Father)
father_figure.role: Former economics professor, now taxi driver
father_figure.function: Represents intellectual defeat, cautionary tale, must find redemption
father_figure.arc: Broken by system, counsels compliance; Vega offers him his job back to pressure Luna; must choose family or safety; finds courage to refuse
father_figure.signature_trait: Still lectures about economics to taxi passengers; brilliant mind in 'wrong' job; teaching Luna online at night
father_figure.key_moment: Act 2B - refuses Vega's offer, reclaims dignity, supports Luna publicly

primary_location.setting: CIUDAD ESPERANZA (metaphorical nation of 'La Patria') - capital city of a once-prosperous South American nation
primary_location.atmosphere: Elegant colonial architecture crumbling; empty shelves contrasted with luxury vehicles; vibrant street life despite scarcity; digital connectivity amid physical decay
unique_elements: Hyperinflation visible everywhere - prices change daily, multiple currencies
Sophisticated surveillance - facial recognition, social credit, internet monitoring
Thriving black markets - physical and digital
Brain drain - young people leaving in waves
Resilient culture - music, art, humor persist despite hardship
Parallel economies - official worthless currency vs. crypto vs. barter
primary_location.production_value: Real locations in historic districts; contrast between decaying grandeur and vibrant street life; digital overlays showing Luna's view of the world (code, patterns, systems)

key_locations.name: REYES FAMILY APARTMENT
key_locations.description: Cramped but loved; Luna's room filled with salvaged tech and monitors; grandmother's illegal book collection; family meals show food scarcity normalized
key_locations.purpose: Emotional anchor, contrast between intimate warmth and external chaos
key_locations.action_potential: Low - but raid scene Act 2B; hiding tech during inspection

key_locations.name: TÍO FELIX'S BODEGA
key_locations.description: Front: Nearly empty shelves, official cameras. Back room: Black market hub, Luna's network meets, analog organization center
key_locations.purpose: Safe space, community hub, comedy relief, bridge between digital and physical resistance
key_locations.action_potential: Medium - secret meetings, near-discoveries, hiding place

key_locations.name: UNIVERSITY COMPUTER LAB
key_locations.description: Luna's former haunt; still sneaks in using old credentials; outdated equipment but crucial internet access
key_locations.purpose: Development/coding scenes, nostalgic, where she meets Mateo (he's painting outside)
key_locations.action_potential: High - surveillance close call, cat-and-mouse with security

key_locations.name: ABANDONED BANK BUILDING
key_locations.description: Gorgeous Art Deco ruin; banks failed spectacularly; now squatters and artists; Mateo's crew base; ironic symbol of failed financial system
key_locations.purpose: Visual metaphor, romantic scenes, community organizing, projection art installations
key_locations.action_potential: High - raid scene, escape through building, final confrontation location

key_locations.name: MINISTRY OF TECHNOLOGY
key_locations.description: Gleaming modern building amid decay; high-tech surveillance center; Vega's domain; everything Luna could have if she sells out
key_locations.purpose: Antagonist's lair, temptation, shows regime's resources, final infiltration target

key_locations.name: ROOFTOP NETWORK
key_locations.description: Various rooftops connected by bridges Luna and Mateo create; above surveillance; where digital meets physical resistance
key_locations.purpose: Symbolic high ground, romantic spots, strategy sessions, escape routes
key_locations.action_potential: Medium-High - chase sequences, meetings, climactic speech

world_rules.technology_level: Contemporary but stratified - regime has advanced surveillance, citizens have makeshift networks
world_rules.economic_reality: Multi-tiered currency system; hyperinflation; everyone has side hustles; success is survival
world_rules.surveillance_state: Sophisticated but not omnipotent; can be outsmarted; facial recognition, social media monitoring, internet tracking
world_rules.social_dynamics: Dark humor as coping; strong family/community bonds; everyone in gray-zone of legality; distrust of authority
world_rules.realism_vs_fantasy: Grounded in realistic tech and economics with slightly heightened wit and cinematic surveillance
world_rules.tone_consistency: Wilde/Twain wit prevents preachiness; darkness leavened by humor; stakes real but hope persists

cultural_texture.language: Spanglish, tech jargon, street slang, philosophical references, economic terms used ironically
cultural_texture.food: Creative cooking with scarcity; sharing meals as resistance; grandmother's recipes as cultural continuity
cultural_texture.art: Street murals, projection art, analog zines, digital art shared on encrypted networks
cultural_texture.music: Local genres mixed with global internet culture; soundtrack of resilience
cultural_texture.humor_style: Self-deprecating about crisis; clever wordplay; satire of government; Gallows humor done warmly

objectives: Establish Luna's isolated, digital-first worldview
Show economic collapse through daily life details
Introduce her automated money-making systems
Establish family stakes and love
Show her dismissive attitude toward 'analog' solutions
Inciting incident: Success attracts wrong attention
Refusal: She thinks she can stay invisible
Break: Realizes she's on Vega's radar—must engage

opening_image.description: Luna's POV: Four monitors showing crypto trading bots, content generation AIs, price arbitrage algorithms, all making money while she sleeps. Pull back: she's in tiny bedroom, family apartment cramped, but her digital world is vast. Voice-over: 'In a country where money evaporates overnight, I built machines that make it appear.'
opening_image.purpose: Establish character, world, tone, central metaphor: digital abundance vs. physical scarcity
opening_image.tone: Witty voice-over, dark comedy, impressive competency, isolation
opening_image.visual_contrast: Cramped physical space vs. infinite digital space; her glowing screens vs. gray morning light
opening_image.thematic_seed: She's escaping into code, not engaging with reality

establish_normal_world.description: Montage of daily survival: Mother's hospital shift, father driving taxi with PhD on display ironically, grandmother maintaining illegal library, uncle's creative bartering at bodega. Luna's routine: monitor systems, avoid human contact, secretly funnel money to family. Witty narration about hyperinflation, surveillance, absurdity normalized. She's planning escape—gathering bitcoin for family to leave. Meet Mateo briefly—he's spray-painting outside university; she dismisses him as 'analog,' he calls her work 'invisible.'
establish_normal_world.purpose: World-building through character routines; establish relationships; Luna's flaw (isolation); show love underneath cynicism
key_dialogue: ABUELA: 'Mija, you can't live in that screen forever.' LUNA: 'Watch me.'
MATEO: 'Your code doesn't exist if nobody sees it.' LUNA: 'That's the point.'
establish_normal_world.visual_style: Handheld, street-level, vibrant despite decay; CONTRAST: Luna's POV shows data overlays, patterns, systems—she sees the world as code
establish_normal_world.setup_payoffs: Plant grandmother's recipe book, father's old lectures online, Valeria working at ministry, uncle's analog network, mother treating network members

inciting_incident.description: Luna's crypto bot makes unexpected breakthrough—goes viral on dark web. Suddenly she's getting thousands of requests. Her network accidentally becomes mutual aid platform: people using her tools don't just make money, they're sharing resources, organizing, helping each other. Uncle shows her: her users started meeting IN PERSON at his bodega. She's horrified and intrigued. Mother reveals: half her patients are from Luna's network, getting medicine via Luna's system. Luna: 'It was supposed to be just math.'
inciting_incident.purpose: External success creates internal crisis; her isolation method accidentally created community; the digital bled into analog
inciting_incident.reaction: Luna wants to shut it down (too visible), but family needs it, people depend on it
inciting_incident.twist: What she thought was escape tool became resistance tool

debate_refusal.description: Luna tries to make network more secure, anonymous, invisible. But people keep connecting, meeting, organizing. Mateo shows up at bodega meeting—he's been using her platform to coordinate street art actions. They clash: she wants invisibility, he wants visibility. She argues pure digital is safer; he argues movements need faces. Meanwhile, VALERIA (former friend, now regime) calls with warning: Comandante Vega noticed the network spike. Offers Luna easy out: take government job, shut down network, family gets benefits. Luna considers it—SAFER. Father pressures her to accept (he's scared). Grandmother, surprisingly, says: 'Running is also a choice, but you can't code your way out of being human.'
debate_refusal.purpose: Show internal debate; present 'easy' path (escape or sell-out); pressure from all sides; hint at real choice ahead
debate_refusal.turning_point: Vega visits family apartment (power play). Charming but threatening. Shows Luna she knows everything. 'Work with me or I shut you down—and I mean all the way down.' Leaves card.
debate_refusal.stakes_raised: Not just about making money anymore—people depending on her; family in danger; her skills weaponized by either side or neither

break_into_act_2.description: Luna decides to meet Vega—plans to outwit her, stay independent, keep network running quietly. Mateo confronts her: 'You can't compromise with them.' Luna: 'Watch me. I'm smarter than all of them.' She walks into Ministry building. Voiceover: 'I had a plan. I always have a plan. I can code my way out of anything.' (We sense her hubris). Visual: Tiny figure entering massive building. HARD CUT to surveillance footage of her—Vega watching, smiling. We realize: Luna thinks she's playing chess, but she doesn't know the rules of the game she's actually in.
break_into_act_2.purpose: Point of no return; commitment to engage; dramatic irony (audience sees she's outmatched); thesis statement: can't algorithm your way out of human conflict
break_into_act_2.visual: Luna's confident walk contrasted with surveillance view showing how tracked she is
break_into_act_2.end_on: Vega's office doors close behind Luna. We stay outside. Ominous.

objectives: Luna tries to play both sides and stay in control
Growing relationship with Mateo shows alternate worldview
Network grows despite/because of attempts to control it
Vega reveals increasingly predatory nature
Luna's digital-only approach repeatedly fails
Build to midpoint revelation about what she's really building
Everything falls apart when she trusts systems over people

fun_and_games_negotiation.description: Luna navigates dangerous dance with Vega. Takes 'consultant' job while secretly maintaining network. Builds in backdoors and safeguards. Codes sabotage into everything she gives regime. Meanwhile, teaches Mateo basic coding—he teaches her about community organizing. They develop grudging respect, attraction. Montage: Luna living double life—regime work by day, network by night. Network grows: people organizing grocery collectives, medicine shares, skill exchanges. Uncle's bodega becomes unofficial hub. Grandmother teaching philosophy to network members. Father starts teaching economics online via Luna's platform. Comic sequences: Luna terrible at analog organizing; Mateo terrible at coding. But together they're effective. Romance builds through witty verbal sparring.
fun_and_games_negotiation.purpose: Deliver on premise—clever coder outwitting surveillance state; develop romance; show network's real-world impact; Luna seeming competent
fun_and_games_negotiation.action_sequence: Close call: Luna nearly caught accessing regime system illegally; smooth-talk escape using charm and technical jargon
fun_and_games_negotiation.character_development: Luna starts to see value in face-to-face organizing but still believes code is superior
witty_dialogue: MATEO: 'You can't spray-paint a revolution.' LUNA: 'You can't spray-paint anything. I've seen your work.'
VEGA: 'You're very talented, Luna.' LUNA: 'I know. That's not the compliment you think it is.'

first_pinch_point.description: Vega demonstrates her power: arrests someone from Luna's network on fabricated charges. Shows Luna surveillance footage of her own family, friends, network members. Message clear: I'm always watching. Forces Luna to implement tracking feature in 'her' platform (but for regime's version, which Luna thinks is separate from her secret network). Luna complies but codes in subtle sabotage. Believes she's still in control.
first_pinch_point.purpose: Remind audience of antagonist's power; raise stakes; show Luna still thinks she can out-clever the problem
first_pinch_point.reaction: Luna doubles down on technical solutions; starts building 'unhackable' system; pulling away from people again because 'they're vulnerable'
first_pinch_point.mateo_conflict: Argues with Mateo—he says trust matters more than encryption; she disagrees

midpoint.description: MAJOR REVELATION: Luna discovers her network isn't just making money or sharing resources—people are organizing politically. Not violently, but coordinating peaceful protests, strikes, mutual aid that's undermining regime control more than any militant group. And it's WORKING. Small victories: corrupt official removed, food price controls defied, information breaking through censorship. Mateo takes her to rooftop: shows her crowd gathering below—organized via her platform. They're chanting messages that came from her network's forums. She's terrified and awed. 'I just wanted to save my family.' Mateo: 'You did. And everyone else's family too.' First real kiss—connection, vulnerability. But TWIST: Valeria calls with warning—Vega knows about the organizing. She's been letting it grow to identify all members. The trap is bigger than Luna thought. Vega doesn't want to stop her—she wants to control her network, weaponize it for regime. Luna realizes: Vega is learning from HER systems to build better surveillance. Every backdoor Luna built, Vega's team is studying. Luna: 'Oh god, I taught them how to do it better.'
midpoint.purpose: False victory (network success) becomes revelation of bigger danger; shift from reactive to proactive; romantic consummation represents emotional availability; stakes raised astronomically; Luna's cleverness backfired
midpoint.shift: Luna must go from 'I can outthink everyone' to 'I need help'; from digital solutions to hybrid approach
midpoint.visual: Rooftop scene—Luna seeing her abstract network as real people for first time; code overlays fade, sees humanity clearly
midpoint.time_clock_starts: Three days until major protest—regime will make move then to round up everyone

second_pinch_point.description: Vega reveals she knows about Luna's double life. Has evidence. Doesn't arrest her—worse: makes offer impossible to refuse. Join regime fully, use network to identify and neutralize 'troublemakers,' or Vega releases evidence that Luna has been defrauding hundreds of people (fabricated, but believable). Would destroy Luna's reputation, network's trust, and justify massive crackdown. Also implies mother could lose medical license, father could be charged as accomplice. Deadline: 48 hours. Valeria present at meeting, won't meet Luna's eyes. Personal betrayal hurts more than threat. Luna realizes: she's been so focused on code, she didn't see the social engineering.
second_pinch_point.purpose: Make it personal; expose Luna's blind spot; impossible choice; deadline pressure
second_pinch_point.emotional_impact: Luna's confidence shattered; realizes her arrogance put everyone in danger
second_pinch_point.vega_speech: 'You thought you were so clever, Luna. But you forgot the oldest truth: power isn't about the code, it's about the people who write it. Welcome to the real world, where I write the rules.'

bad_guys_close_in.description: Everything falls apart systematically. Luna tries technical solutions—all fail. Regime has adapted to her methods. She tries to warn network—Vega's team intercepts communications. Mateo organizes physical meetings—several members arrested. Uncle's bodega raided; he's questioned but released (warning shot). Luna's systems start glitching—realizes Vega's team is using her own backdoors against her. Paranoia sets in: Who's compromised? Can she trust anyone? Pulls away from Mateo (thinks it's safer for him). Father, under pressure, admits Vega offered him professorship back if Luna complies—didn't tell her because he wanted her to choose freely, but now she feels betrayed. Mother exhausted from extra shifts, afraid to sleep. Grandmother's library seized. Network members going dark out of fear. Luna isolated in bedroom, trying to code her way out, failing. Montage of systems failing, surveillance closing in, family fracturing. She's back where she started—alone with screens—but now it's a prison, not a kingdom.
bad_guys_close_in.purpose: Systematic destruction of everything built; isolate protagonist; force recognition that technical solutions insufficient; test all relationships
bad_guys_close_in.losses: Trust, safety, network, relationship with Mateo, family unity, her confidence
bad_guys_close_in.visual: Bright screens now oppressive; monitoring her as much as she monitors; her reflection in black screen—she can't see clearly anymore

all_is_lost.description: The night before Vega's deadline. Luna decides to accept the deal—she'll turn over the network, identify leaders, work for regime. Seems like only way to save family. But first, she goes to tell Mateo. Finds him at abandoned bank with his art crew, planning to project manifesto she wrote (without permission) onto Ministry building during tomorrow's protest. She explodes—they'll all be arrested. Tries to stop it. Fight escalates—she says things she doesn't mean, calling him naive, stupid, 'analog.' He calls her coward, says she hides behind code because she's afraid to be human. She storms out. Walking home through empty streets, passes places that now mean something: bodega where network met, university where she met Mateo, rooftop where they kissed. Sees Valeria waiting at her building. Valeria: 'I tried to warn you. I'm sorry. Vega wanted me to tell you: if you don't show up tomorrow with the data, your mother gets arrested at hospital. Charges already filed.' Hands Luna envelope with 'evidence.' Leaves. Luna enters apartment—family asleep, exhausted. She sits at computer, prepares to package all network data for Vega. Voiceover: 'I thought I was so smart. Turns out, I was just alone. Maybe that's the same thing.' Opens grandmother's recipe book, randomly given to her for 'safekeeping.' Inside: handwritten notes from network members, letters to Luna, printed photos of meetings, analog backup of the community she tried to digitize. Note from grandmother: 'Some things matter too much to be only ones and zeros. -A.C.' Luna breaks down crying—first time we've seen her cry.
all_is_lost.purpose: Lowest point; 'whiff of death' (death of hope, community, who she thought she was); ultimate isolation; realization of what really matters; sets up transformation
all_is_lost.emotional_beat: Character break down; audience empathy peak; feels unwinnable
all_is_lost.symbolic: Recipe book = analog wisdom wins; family recipes = what sustains us isn't algorithmic; handwritten = human touch matters

dark_night_of_soul.description: Luna stays up all night. Not coding—reading the letters and notes. People's stories. Family she helped reunite. Medicine her system helped deliver. Student who could afford university. Grandmother who got glasses. Stories of connection, not just transaction. Realizes: she was so focused on the SYSTEM, she missed the PEOPLE. The algorithm was never the point—the network was. And networks aren't code; they're trust. She's been solving the wrong problem. Vega can copy her code, crack her encryption, but can't replicate trust. That's analog. That's human. That's what she dismissed. Morning comes. Mother wakes, makes coffee (scarcity means real coffee is love language). Joins Luna. They don't speak for a while. MOTHER: 'Whatever you decide, we're with you. You don't have to save us alone.' LUNA: 'I can't save us alone. That was the problem.' Mother hugs her. Luna looks at screens differently now—tools, not solutions. Opens laptop, starts typing, but differently now. Voice-over: 'You know what's funny about algorithms? They're deterministic. You put in same input, get same output. But people? People are variables. And that's not a bug. That's the whole point.' Grandmother joins them, brings the recipe book. ABUELA: 'Ready to try a new recipe?' LUNA: 'I don't cook, Abuela.' ABUELA: 'Neither do revolutionaries. Until they do.' Luna smiles—first genuine smile in pages. She has a plan, but this time it's not just code.
dark_night_of_soul.purpose: Internal transformation; realization; finds true strength in vulnerability and community; hope restored through human connection; setup for new approach
dark_night_of_soul.realization: Intelligence isn't about having all answers; it's knowing which questions to ask. And sometimes you need to ask people, not computers.
dark_night_of_soul.visual: Sunrise through window; warm light replacing cold screen glow; three generations of women together; recipe book in foreground

break_into_act_3.description: Luna reaches out to Mateo—apologizes not with words but with action: sends him detailed code for how to temporarily blind surveillance cameras using regime's own systems against them. Message: 'I'm sorry. Let's cook something together. -L' Meets with Valeria secretly—confronts her. Valeria breaks: she's been feeding info to Luna all along, hates regime, but trapped. Luna: 'Time to get untrapped.' Rallies family: needs everyone's skills. Father's economics knowledge, mother's medical network, grandmother's analog organization, uncle's distribution network, Mateo's art and organizing, Valeria's inside access, Luna's code. Not digital OR analog—both. Hybrid. Montage of preparation: teaching network members physical security; Mateo teaching Luna street smarts; building redundant analog communication (uncle's delivery network); setting up deadman switches; most importantly—TRUSTING PEOPLE with pieces of plan. She doesn't have to be smartest person in room; she has to be person who brings room together. Family dinner scene—everyone contributing. Grandmother leads discussion about philosophy of resistance. Father provides economic analysis. Mother discusses practical logistics. Uncle provides comic relief and surprising strategic insights. Mateo and Luna finish each other's sentences—digital and analog synthesis. Final shot: Luna closes laptop, joins family at table. Voiceover: 'Every algorithm needs input. I was wrong about what I should be programming. It's not people. It's with people.' SMASH CUT: Black screen. Title card: 'THE PROTOCOL' (Their plan name). Act 3 begins.
break_into_act_3.purpose: Rebirth; new plan based on new wisdom; rally allies; show growth through action; hybrid approach; hope restored; community united; set up final confrontation
break_into_act_3.visual: Warm family scene contrasts with cold Act 2B isolation; everyone at table—literal and metaphorical coming together; Luna's screens visible in background but not dominating
break_into_act_3.tone_shift: From despair to determined hope; from clever to wise; from isolated to connected

objectives: Execute hybrid digital-analog plan
Outmaneuver Vega ideologically and practically
Valeria's redemption
Public revelation of truth
Character arc completion for Luna
Answer thematic question
Resolve all plot threads with hope, not naive optimism

finale_begins.description: Morning of protest. Luna supposed to deliver network data to Vega at Ministry. Instead, she shows up with different data: complete documentation of Vega's corruption, surveillance overreach, fabricated charges. But she doesn't threaten exposure—yet. Vega: 'You have nothing. I have your family.' Luna: 'You taught me power isn't in the code. It's in the people who write it. Thanks for that lesson.' Meanwhile, the hybrid plan launches: Mateo's crew creates massive projection art installations using Luna's code to temporarily blind surveillance; uncle's network distributes physical leaflets with QR codes to encrypted forums; grandmother leads in-person groups while Luna's system provides secure communication; mother's medical network provides safe spaces; father teaches economics of what they're building (alternative economy) to crowds; Valeria feeds false data to Ministry systems. The protest isn't violent—it's COORDINATED. People following hybrid protocol: analog presence, digital support. It's beautiful and effective. Luna watches from Ministry window as city comes alive with people taking streets in creative ways—flash mobs, singing, projection art, people simply standing together. Vega sees it too: 'You did this?' Luna: 'No. We did.' Vega calls security, but systems are glitching (Luna and Valeria's joint sabotage). Phone system overloaded (uncle's network coordinating). Surveillance blind in key areas (Mateo's tech). For the first time, Vega looks worried.
finale_begins.purpose: Set up final confrontation; show hybrid plan working; demonstrate growth; raise stakes to maximum; show antagonist losing control
finale_begins.tone: Determined, tactical, community in action, building energy
finale_begins.visual: Split screen: Ministry interior (Vega isolated, systems failing) vs. streets (people connecting, systems supporting); Luna's POV shows both—digital and analog unified

ideological_confrontation.description: Vega locks down Ministry—Luna trapped inside (planned). Captain Ramos tries to arrest her, but Valeria intervenes—reveals she's been working with Luna, provides evidence of her own that exposes Ramos's corruption. Chaos in Ministry. Luna and Vega face off in surveillance center. PHILOSOPHICAL BATTLE: Vega argues order, security, control necessary for survival; Luna counters with community, trust, freedom. But Luna's argument is nuanced—she doesn't claim freedom solves everything, just that humans deserve to fail on their own terms rather than succeed in cages. Vega: 'You're naive. I was like you once. You'll learn.' Luna: 'No. You'll remember.' Shows Vega feed from streets: not chaos, but organization. Not destruction, but construction. People helping each other, sharing resources, building something. Vega: 'It won't last.' Luna: 'Maybe not. But we'll have lived it. That's more than you can say in your tower.' Vega reveals final trap: counter-protocol already running—mass arrests queued, Luna's family already in custody, deadman switch (if Luna doesn't surrender, arrests execute automatically). Luna smiles: 'I learned that trick from you. Here's what I learned from my grandmother: recipes need time and the right ingredients. Your deadman switch? Already neutralized. My network found everyone you had staged—warned them, got them to safety. Uncle's analog network moves faster than your digital one when people trust each other.' Vega checks systems—it's true. Her power is digital, and Luna+Valeria crashed it. But more than that: her AUTHORITY is gone—even her team is watching protest feed, some crying, realizing what they've been doing.
ideological_confrontation.purpose: Philosophical resolution; show Luna's growth; demonstrate hybrid superiority not through violence but through better organizing; defeat antagonist ideologically before physically
ideological_confrontation.dialogue_highlight: VEGA: 'You can't algorithm away human nature—people are selfish.' LUNA: 'You're right. That's why I stopped trying to algorithm people and started working with them. Human nature isn't just selfish. It's cooperative, creative, beautiful. You forgot that.'
ideological_confrontation.emotional_core: Not revenge—sadness for Vega's path; Luna sees herself in Vega (what she could have become)

action_sequence.description: Captain Ramos, fanatic true believer, won't let Luna leave. Takes her hostage, declares martial law, tries to force loyalty from Ministry staff. Tense standoff. But then—Mateo's projection art flashes onto Ministry building exterior: Luna's entire case against regime, documented, visible to everyone. Public, irrefutable, beautiful. QR codes lead to Luna's most elegant code: distributed network no one entity controls—evidence replicated across thousands of devices. Can't shut down without shutting down internet entirely (which would prove their authoritarianism). Ramos tries anyway—but Valeria and technical team refuse orders. Ministry staff, seeing truth, stand down. Ramos grabs Luna, tries to flee to rooftop helipad. Luna and Ramos fight—she's not trained, but she's scrappy and smart. Uses environment (server racks, cable, equipment). Mateo and protestors arrive (broke through barricades—people power). Standoff on rooftop. Ramos defeated not by violence but by realization he's alone—even Vega won't help him (she's staring at footage of what she's done, processing). Ramos arrested by his own officers. Luna and Mateo reunion—kiss, relieved embrace. Below, protest becomes celebration—people dancing in streets, sharing food, singing. New government officials (emboldened by protest) arrive to arrest Vega. She doesn't resist. Looks at Luna: 'What now?' Luna: 'Now? We build something better. And I'm really going to need that to be
because I have no idea how to actually govern. I just know how to build networks.' Vega almost smiles. 'That might be enough.' She's taken away, but with some dignity.
action_sequence.purpose: Physical climax; resolve Ramos threat; Vega's defeat is graceful, not cruel; show triumph of cooperation over force; romantic resolution; celebrate community victory
action_sequence.action_beats: Rooftop confrontation, Luna using intelligence not strength, community literally rising to help, non-violent revolution succeeding
action_sequence.visual: Rooftop high above city—can see celebrations below; sunrise breaking (new day metaphor); Luna between Mateo and screens—she's integrated both worlds

resolution_montage.description: Weeks later. Reform government establishing transition. Luna helping design transparent systems—but now with oversight, community input, analog checks. Father teaching at university again. Mother leads healthcare collective. Grandmother publishing her philosophy writings. Uncle's bodega now official community center. Valeria working on reformed digital infrastructure—she and Luna collaborate, friendship healing. Luna and Mateo's relationship deepening—she's learning street art, he's learning code; hybrid partnership. Luna's original network evolved: now it's democratic, transparent, community-governed. She's not the architect anymore—she's a participant. Voice-over: 'Turns out, the best algorithm is the one that adapts to the data, not forces data to adapt to it. And people aren't data. They're the whole point.' Scene at family dinner—expanded now, includes Mateo, Valeria, network friends—everyone cooking together (grandmother's recipes, but variations). Luna away from screens, present, laughing. Uncle makes terrible joke, everyone groans. Father discussing new economic theories. Mother showing photos from medical collective. Mateo and Luna exchange glances—love, partnership, home. Grandmother proposes toast: 'To algorithms that bring us together, not drive us apart. To the intelligence of the heart.' They drink. Luna glances at laptop (old habit)—but closes it, returns attention to table.
resolution_montage.purpose: Show new equilibrium; all characters' arcs resolved; demonstrate sustainable change; Luna's transformation complete; found family moment
resolution_montage.tone: Warm, hopeful but realistic, earned happiness, community
resolution_montage.music: Local folk music mixed with electronic beats—hybrid soundtrack

final_image.description: Luna on rooftop—same one where she and Mateo first kissed. But this time, she's not alone. Mateo, grandmother, core network members with her. Below, city transformed: new murals, community gardens in former empty lots, people in streets but not protesting—just living, connected. Luna's laptop open, but she's teaching a young girl how to code—passing it on. Mateo adds street art to the lesson. Grandmother reads philosophy. It's integrated—digital, analog, human. Luna voice-over: 'My grandmother was right—you can't algorithm your way out of being human. But you can algorithm your way into being more human. Into connection. Into community. Into hope. That's the code that matters. The one written by people, for people, with people.' Camera pulls back: rooftop garden now exists where before was concrete. They're planting literal and metaphorical seeds. Luna and Mateo hold hands, looking at city—their city, their community, their home. Final frame freezes on them, overlaid with code: not ominous surveillance code, but their hybrid protocol—beautiful, open-source, accessible. Last line, grandmother's voice: 'The best recipe is one you share.' BLACK. Text: 'Dedicated to all those who build networks of hope in dark times.' Over credits: screenshots of real communities using technology for mutual aid; no specific country named but universal resonance; open-source code for mutual aid networks listed; organization links for how to get involved.
final_image.purpose: Mirror opening image but show change; Luna integrated not isolated; digital+analog synthesis; hope without naivety; call to action; circular but evolved; ending that resonates emotionally and intellectually
final_image.visual: Warm sunset light (vs. cold morning in opening); community present (vs. isolation); Luna engaged with world (vs. behind screens); growth visible; same setting but transformed
final_image.thematic_payoff: Technology serves humanity, not replaces it; individual genius+community cooperation=change; staying and building beats escaping; trust is the real currency

a_story_external.thread_name: Build sustainable income system / Evade regime control
a_story_external.act_1: Create automated money-making system; attract regime attention
a_story_external.act_2a: Navigate double life—regime consultant while maintaining network
a_story_external.midpoint: Discover network became political organizing tool; Vega wants to weaponize it
a_story_external.act_2b: Systems fail; Vega's ultimatum; must surrender or family suffers
a_story_external.act_3: Execute hybrid digital-analog resistance protocol; outmaneuver Vega
a_story_external.resolution: Regime weakened; Luna's network becomes transparent community tool

b_story_internal.thread_name: Learn to trust people over systems / Connect authentically
b_story_internal.act_1: Isolated, dismissive of human 'messiness,' trusts only code
b_story_internal.act_2a: Reluctant connection with Mateo; sees value in analog but still prioritizes digital
b_story_internal.midpoint: First vulnerability—kiss, admits fear, but still defaults to control
b_story_internal.act_2b: Isolation fails completely; realizes code can't solve human problems; breaks down
b_story_internal.act_3: Embraces hybrid approach; trusts others with plan; present and open
b_story_internal.resolution: Fully integrated—still brilliant coder but now connected human; teaches others

c_story_romance.act_1: Meet-cute through conflict; mutual dismissal; attraction despite differences
c_story_romance.act_2a: Forced collaboration; witty banter; teach each other; first kiss at midpoint
c_story_romance.midpoint: Romantic and ideological union—both vulnerabilities accepted
c_story_romance.act_2b: Luna pushes him away 'for safety'; fight where truths hurt
c_story_romance.act_3: Reunion through action; partnership in resistance; love through respect
c_story_romance.resolution: Equal partners—hybrid relationship mirrors hybrid solution; building life together

subplot_1_family.purpose: Emotional stakes; show different forms of intelligence/contribution
subplot_1_family.key_beats: Father's humiliation vs. redemption; mother's sacrifice vs. leadership; grandmother's wisdom vs. risk
subplot_1_family.resolution: Each family member integral to victory; strengthened bonds; expanded family

subplot_2_valeria.purpose: Show alternate path; moral complexity; cost of compromise
subplot_2_valeria.key_beats: Appears as betrayer; revealed as double agent; critical assist in Act 3; forgiveness
subplot_2_valeria.resolution: Rebuilds friendship with Luna; works on reformed systems; saved by choosing courage

subplot_3_vega.thread_name: Antagonist's arc from believer to realization
subplot_3_vega.purpose: Show how good intentions become authoritarianism; Luna's dark mirror
subplot_3_vega.key_beats: Reasonable → controlling → desperate → broken → glimpse of redemption
subplot_3_vega.resolution: Defeated but not destroyed; perhaps can change; ambiguous hope

set_pieces_major_sequences.description: First physical network meeting; Luna attends reluctantly; near-raid by police
key_beats: Luna arrives skeptical, sees diverse group of people her systems helped
Stories shared—human impact of her algorithms
Mateo presents idea for coordinated action
Police arrive for 'inspection'—everyone hides
Uncle's comic misdirection while people escape through back
Luna and Mateo last to leave, close call on rooftop escape
set_pieces_major_sequences.stakes: First time Luna sees network as people not users; everyone could be arrested
set_pieces_major_sequences.emotional_component: Luna begins to care about specific individuals; Mateo saves her practically
set_pieces_major_sequences.tone: Community warmth interrupted by danger; comedy and tension blend
set_pieces_major_sequences.production_notes: Practical location; ensemble cast intro; establishes geography for later

set_pieces_major_sequences.location: Abandoned bank building - projection art reveal
set_pieces_major_sequences.description: Mateo shows Luna his crew's art installation; combines with her code; raid interrupts
key_beats: Gorgeous projection art on building facade
Luna provides code that makes it interactive with crowd
Moment of beauty—digital and analog perfect synthesis
First kiss during the light show
Raid begins—scatter and run
Chase through building's beautiful decay
Luna uses building knowledge (Mateo taught her) to escape
Mateo arrested—Luna barely escapes
set_pieces_major_sequences.stakes: Mateo's freedom; Luna's guilt; romance interrupted by reality
set_pieces_major_sequences.emotional_component: Peak of hope before crash; love scene interrupted; Luna's helplessness without code
set_pieces_major_sequences.production_notes: Signature visual sequence; practical projections; parkour-style chase; key romantic beat

set_pieces_major_sequences.description: Final confrontation location; Luna trapped inside during climax
key_beats: Luna voluntarily enters with 'data' for Vega
Reveals she and Valeria sabotaged systems
Philosophical confrontation with Vega
Ramos takes her hostage
Fight through Ministry building
Mateo's projection art reveals truth to public on building exterior
Rooftop standoff
Community breaks through—people power vs. authority
Vega's ideological defeat watching her systems fail
set_pieces_major_sequences.stakes: Everything—Luna's life, regime change, thematic resolution
set_pieces_major_sequences.emotional_component: Luna uses all lessons—digital skills, analog tactics, trust in people; synthesis
set_pieces_major_sequences.tone: Tense build to triumphant release; not violent revolution but coordinated non-violent action
set_pieces_major_sequences.production_notes: Major set piece; interior/exterior; rooftop finale; crowd sequences; projection mapping VFX

emotional_beats_calendar.purpose: Track Luna's emotional journey separate from plot
emotional_beats_calendar.tonal_notes: Wilde/Twain wit prevents this from being depressing; darkness leavened by humor throughout; earned emotion, not manipulation

characteristics: Tech jargon mixed with street slang
signature_phrases: That's not a bug, that's a feature
protagonist_voice.growth_indicator: Begins using 'we' instead of 'I'; pauses before speaking; asks questions instead of declaring
protagonist_voice.example_early: LUNA: 'People are just poorly optimized algorithms anyway.'
protagonist_voice.example_late: LUNA: 'People aren't algorithms. That's what makes them amazing.'

characteristics: Maternal/teacher tone (patronizing but genuinely believes she's teaching)
signature_phrases: I'm trying to help you, Luna
Someone has to make the hard choices
antagonist_voice.contrast_to_hero: Believes in systems over people; Luna learns to believe in people through systems
antagonist_voice.complexity: Makes valid points; audience should understand her logic even while disagreeing

supporting_cast_voices.mateo: Passionate, poetic, street-smart, quotes Wilde and Marx, earnest without naivety, 'feels' while Luna 'thinks'
supporting_cast_voices.abuela: Wise, witty, philosophical references natural, subverts 'sweet grandmother' stereotype—she's sharp
supporting_cast_voices.uncle: Comic but not stupid; malapropisms and tech-illiterate humor hide shrewd intelligence
supporting_cast_voices.mother: Practical, warm, strong, medical precision in speech, emotional directness Luna lacks
supporting_cast_voices.father: Academic even in despair, economic terminology, defeated early/empowered late, gentle
supporting_cast_voices.valeria: Corporate buzzwords masking pain, trying to convince herself, breaks into authentic pain

general_rules: Humor in darkness—but never mocking suffering
Each character wants something each scene
Code-switching based on context (Luna different with grandmother vs. Vega)

key_dialogue_moments.act_1_thesis: MATEO: 'You can't code a revolution.' LUNA: 'Watch me.'
key_dialogue_moments.midpoint_shift: LUNA: 'I wanted to save my family.' MATEO: 'You did. And everyone else's too.'
key_dialogue_moments.all_is_lost: LUNA: 'I thought I was so smart. Turns out I was just alone.'
key_dialogue_moments.transformation: ABUELA: 'You can't algorithm your way out of being human.' LUNA: 'No. But I can algorithm my way into being more human.'
key_dialogue_moments.final_answer: VEGA: 'What now?' LUNA: 'Now we build something better. Together.'

color_palette.act_1: Desaturated reality with vibrant screens—Luna's world is digital color, physical world is gray
color_palette.act_2a: Increasing warmth as she connects—Mateo brings color to physical world; street art pops
color_palette.midpoint: Full color—both worlds vibrant when unified
color_palette.act_2b: Darkness, shadows, even screens become oppressive blue, surveillance green
color_palette.act_3: Sunrise gold, community warmth, balanced palette—digital and analog both vibrant

camera_language.luna_isolated: Tight frames, screens reflection in glasses, surrounded by technology
camera_language.luna_connecting: Opening up frames, two-shots with Mateo, depth of field showing world beyond screens
camera_language.surveillance_pov: Clinical, high-angle, multiple screens, digital overlays—dehumanizing
camera_language.community_scenes: Handheld, warm, intimate, Dutch angles energy
camera_language.action_sequences: Kinetic but clear, parkour-style, environment interaction, geographic clarity
camera_language.finale: Epic wides establishing scale, intimate close-ups for emotion, balanced composition showing synthesis

visual_motifs: Screens: Luna's interface with world → windows to community → tools among others
Broken glass: System cracks literal and metaphorical
Empty storefronts: Economic collapse visible; later transformed by art/community
Grandmother's recipe book: Analog wisdom, handwritten, contrasts with Luna's screens
Projection art: Ephemeral beauty, public truth, synthesis of digital and analog
Rooftops: Above surveillance, perspective, freedom, where Luna connects with both worlds
Code on screen: Early chaotic/incomprehensible; later beautiful, readable, open-source aesthetic
signature_shots: Opening: Luna's reflection in four monitors, surrounded by code, isolated in bedroom
Midpoint: Rooftop, Luna seeing crowd below, code overlay fades revealing humanity
Dark night: Recipe book close-up, handwritten notes, Luna's tear falling on page
Finale: Projection on Ministry building—Luna's code becomes public art, truth visible
Final: Rooftop garden, Luna teaching, screens present but not dominating, community visible below

screen_text_design.approach: Code and interfaces should be beautiful, readable, tell story
screen_text_design.luna_coding: Elegant, sophisticated UI/UX, custom terminals, aesthetic code
screen_text_design.regime_surveillance: Clinical, corporate, facial recognition boxes, social credit scores, dehumanizing
screen_text_design.network_interface: Warm, collaborative, user-generated content visible, human names not numbers
screen_text_design.final_protocol: Open-source aesthetic, commented code, accessible, inviting

pacing_rhythm.act_1: Quick establishment, wit-driven, accelerating to break into Act 2
pacing_rhythm.act_2a: Action-dialogue-romance rhythm, building momentum, peaks at midpoint
pacing_rhythm.midpoint: Major peak then brief respite for processing
pacing_rhythm.act_2b: Sustained pressure, compression, systematic destruction, deceleration to dark night stillness
pacing_rhythm.act_3: Steady build through preparation, accelerating through action, sustained climax, quick warm resolution

scene_length_guide.dialogue: 2-3 pages—keep it snappy, Wilde wit is efficient

pacing_rhythm.rhythm_notes: Alternate between cerebral (coding, philosophy) and visceral (street, action); between isolation (Luna alone) and community (ensemble scenes); between digital (screen time) and analog (physical world)

how_theme_appears.dialogue: Characters debate digital vs. analog, individual vs. community, escape vs. engagement
how_theme_appears.action: Luna's successes come when she combines approaches; failures when she isolates
how_theme_appears.visuals: Screens vs. faces, code vs. handwriting, algorithms vs. recipes, surveillance vs. art
how_theme_appears.structure: Three-act progression mirrors learning curve: isolation → attempted control → synthesis

theme_per_act.act_1: Individual genius can solve everything (thesis—Luna believes this)
theme_per_act.act_2: Systems fail without human element (antithesis—Luna learns this)
theme_per_act.act_3: Synthesis of digital tools and human community creates change (synthesis—Luna embodies this)

symbol_payoffs.recipe_book: Introduced Act 1 as 'old-fashioned'; becomes literal and metaphorical guide Act 2B; shared with next generation Act 3
symbol_payoffs.broken_screens: Luna's monitors glitch when stressed; regime surveillance fails when people unite; final image shows screens as tools not barriers
symbol_payoffs.empty_storefronts: Economic collapse visual; transformed by street art Act 2; become community spaces Act 3
symbol_payoffs.projection_art: Introduced as Mateo's 'useless' passion; becomes key revolutionary tool; synthesis of their skills

budget_indicators.value_on_screen: Authentic locations, strong ensemble cast, practical effects, limited VFX for screens/projections

trailer_moments: Luna: 'I can algorithm anything' montage showing her skills
Mateo and Luna's witty exchanges and chemistry
Vega: 'Work with me or everyone you love suffers'
Projection art on Ministry building—visual spectacle
marketability.poster_image: Luna in foreground with laptop, code reflecting in her face; behind her, crowd of people in street; Mateo beside her; grandmother's hand on shoulder; Ministry building looming; divided screen aesthetic showing digital and physical worlds merging
marketability.one_sheet_tagline: In a world that crashed, she coded hope. // Some revolutions are written in code. // The most dangerous algorithm is hope.
marketability.international_appeal: Universal themes (oppression, family, coming-of-age, tech); no specific country named; relevant to many contexts; youth appeal; tech relevance

festival_positioning.target_festivals: Sundance, SXSW, Tribeca, Toronto—prestige with commercial appeal
festival_positioning.awards_potential: Best Original Screenplay, Best Actress (Luna), Breakthrough Performance (ensemble), Best Editing
festival_positioning.social_relevance: Timely—digital economy, authoritarianism, youth activism, AI ethics, crypto, surveillance capitalism

franchise_potential.sequel_hooks: Luna's network expanding internationally; other regimes; Vega's potential redemption arc; new threats to digital freedom
franchise_potential.recurring_elements: Luna-Mateo partnership, family, hybrid resistance model, wit and heart
franchise_potential.expandability: Medium—story complete but world and approach could continue; anthology potential in universe

casting_notes.luna: 18, Latina, brilliant, witty, must carry film, chemistry crucial, needs comedy and drama range
casting_notes.mateo: 19, Latino, charismatic, passionate, physical (art/action), romantic lead qualities
casting_notes.vega: 40s, Latina, sophisticated, complex villain, must be sympathetic and threatening
casting_notes.abuela: 70s, Latina, comedic timing, philosophical depth, scene-stealer
casting_notes.ensemble: Strong character actors, authentic to culture, chemistry as family/community

script_formatting_notes.white_space: Abundant—wit reads better with air; no dense paragraphs
script_formatting_notes.action_lines: Present tense, sharp prose, visual, economical—Wilde style even in description
script_formatting_notes.voice_over: Frequent in Act 1 (Luna's perspective), sparse in Act 2 (experiencing not observing), returns transformed Act 3
script_formatting_notes.on_screen_text: Code, messages, interfaces designed and described specifically—part of storytelling
script_formatting_notes.montages: Several—time compression for skill-building, network growth, preparation
script_formatting_notes.intercuts: Between digital and physical action; Luna's POV and surveillance POV; preparation and execution
script_formatting_notes.spanish_language: Authentic use when appropriate; family scenes mix languages naturally; not subtitled in description
script_formatting_notes.technical_accuracy: Code and tech should be researched but not bog down story; consult experts but prioritize clarity

llm_generation_instructions.primary_directive: Generate a screenplay that balances Oscar Wilde wit with Mark Twain social commentary, set in a metaphorical Venezuela-like oppressive state, following an 18-year-old coder who learns that technology without humanity is just another form of isolation.
tone_mandates: Witty and sharp but never cruel
Dark subject matter leavened by humor
Social commentary through character not preaching
character_priorities: Luna must be brilliant but flawed, witty but vulnerable, growing visibly
Mateo equals her—different intelligence, not lesser
Vega must make good points even as villain
Supporting cast all contribute—no one is just functional
Romance earned through respect and partnership
structural_requirements: Hit all three-act beats within 5 pages of target
Every scene advances plot OR character (preferably both)
Theme present but subtle until earned in climax
Visual storytelling primary—describe what we SEE
thematic_integration: Digital vs. analog tension in every act, synthesis in Act 3
Individual genius vs. community power—both matter, balanced
Escape vs. engagement—staying and building wins
Trust as true currency—algorithms serve, don't replace
Show these themes through action, don't state them

quality_control_checkpoints.is_wit_consistent: Wilde/Twain tone in dialogue and description throughout
quality_control_checkpoints.are_stakes_personal: Not just 'save country'—save family, self, specific people
quality_control_checkpoints.is_vega_complex: Makes good points, sympathetic motivation, ideological not cartoonish
quality_control_checkpoints.do_all_plots_resolve: A-story (network/regime), B-story (Luna's growth), C-story (romance), subplots (family, Valeria)
quality_control_checkpoints.is_ending_satisfying: Hopeful but realistic, mirrors opening transformed, theme answered

generation_tips.start_with_voice: Establish Luna's witty voice-over immediately—sets tone
generation_tips.use_montage: Compress time while building world—more efficient than scenes
generation_tips.contrast_visuals: Gray oppression vs. vibrant screens; isolating technology vs. connecting art
generation_tips.layer_dialogue: Subtext, wit, character, plot all in every exchange
generation_tips.earn_emotions: Setup small, payoff big—grandmother's recipe book introduced pages before it matters
generation_tips.show_don't_tell: Hyperinflation through prices changing, not explanation; surveillance through behavior changes
generation_tips.cultural_authenticity: Research Venezuelan/Latin American context but keep metaphorical; universal specificity

avoid_these_pitfalls: Tech-bro protagonist—Luna is brilliant but must learn humility
Simplistic villain—Vega represents real ideology, must be defeated ideologically
Savior narrative—Luna catalyzes change, doesn't single-handedly save everyone
Unrealistic tech—consult experts, keep it grounded even when heightened
Poverty porn—show dignity in hardship, resilience in community
Naive optimism—ending hopeful but shows ongoing work needed
llm_generation_instructions.success_criteria: Audience should: laugh frequently, cry in Act 2B/3, learn something about technology and humanity, feel inspired to act, remember Luna and Mateo, quote the dialogue, understand the political commentary without feeling lectured, want to build community networks themselves.
